qas.question: By what year was demand so great that one railroad line could no longer keep up with the demand?
What was the name of the new railway that was constructed to transport tourists to Atlantic City after 1878?
What was the name of the hotel that took up a full city block?
Besides massive hotels, what else was appearing all over Atlantic City during this period?
What were the names of the four avenues that surrounded The United States Hotel?

answers.text: Atlantic, Pacific, Delaware, and Maryland Avenues

context: By <a0_0>1878<a0_0/>, because of the growing popularity of the city, one railroad line could no longer keep up with demand. Soon, the <a1_0>Philadelphia and Atlantic City Railway<a1_0/> was also constructed to transport tourists to Atlantic City. At this point massive hotels like The United States and Surf House, as well as smaller <a3_0>rooming houses<a3_0/>, had sprung up all over town. <a2_0>The United States Hotel<a2_0/> took up a full city block between <a4_0>Atlantic, Pacific, Delaware, and Maryland Avenues<a4_0/>. These hotels were not only impressive in size, but featured the most updated amenities, and were considered quite luxurious for their time.
